content.subtitle: Subject Positioning
text: Supine position, lower limb in slight internal rotation, with the knee maintained at approximately 20-30° of flexion[1]

content.subtitle: Anatomical Landmarks and Palpation
text: Locate and palpate the fibular head, lateral tibial plateau, and lateral femoral epicondyle

vues.title: Longitudinal View
objectifs: Examination of the lateral collateral ligament
positionnement: In longitudinal view (parallel to the long axis of the tibia), place the distal (caudal) end of the probe on the fibular head
Slowly rotate the probe until obtaining the longest possible image of the LCL, i.e., when the probe is optimally aligned with the ligament[1]

texte: The femur appears in the lower left portion of the image as a curved area (two convex sides and a concave middle) with hyperechoic margins

The tibia appears to the right (distally) of the femur and can be recognized by its cortical bone (hyperechoic) which is highly impermeable to ultrasound waves (explaining the hypoechoic area beneath it).
The collateral ligament is visible superficial to the tibia and femur, appearing as a slightly hyperechoic band with fibrillar echotexture and well-defined margins.

text: The lateral collateral ligament [LCL] is a ligament of the posterolateral aspect of the knee that is part of the lateral supporting structures of the knee. Similar to the medial aspect of the knee, the stabilizing structures of the lateral aspect of the knee are organized in three layers, according to their relative depth. From the most superficial to the deepest structures, we find:[1]

• Superficial layer: iliotibial band (anterior) and biceps femoris tendon (posterior)
  • Intermediate layer: lateral patellar retinaculum & patellofemoral ligaments (anterior) and lateral collateral ligament (posterior)
  • Deep layer: lateral portion of the joint capsule and the arcuate and fabellofibular ligaments
Some stabilizing structures of the knee are sometimes grouped under the terms 'arcuate ligament complex' or 'posterolateral ligament complex' of the knee, which includes:[4][9]

• The lateral collateral ligament
  • The arcuate popliteal ligament
  • The popliteofibular ligament
  • The fabellofibular ligament (if a fabella is present)
  • The posterior third of the lateral capsule
Also, depending on the authors, the term 'arcuate ligament complex of the knee' may also encompass:

• The tendon-aponeurosis unit formed by the popliteus muscle
  • The biceps femoris tendon
  • The popliteal meniscal ligament
  • The lateral head of the gastrocnemius muscle

The LCL is the primary restraint to varus stress of the knee and also helps prevent knee hyperextension. Additionally, it has been established that knee flexion movements cause relaxation of the lateral collateral ligament[1]. According to a 2009 study[12], the LCL is isometric (or nearly so) for knee flexion angles from 0° to 70°, and for angles > 70°, it shortens (thus relaxes) at a rate of 1.2 mm/10° of knee flexion (see attached graph, where 'LCL' refers to 'lateral collateral ligament').

content.subtitle: Lateral Collateral Ligament Injury
text: The LCL is less frequently injured than the medial collateral ligament (which is also true for all lateral knee stabilizing structures compared to medial ones). Sprains, strains, or ruptures of the LCL typically result from excessive varus stress and are often associated with anterior cruciate ligament injuries or other intra-articular lesions[1].

Since ultrasonography imaging has limited utility in visualizing intra-articular knee structures, and considering that LCL injuries are often accompanied by intra-articular lesions, magnetic resonance imaging is generally used when an LCL injury is suspected[1].
On ultrasound examination, the ruptured ligament appears thickened, and it can be difficult (if not impossible) to distinguish between a partial and complete rupture[1].
